title: The Expressiveness Spectrum Theorem
subtitle: THE THIRTY-FOURTH BREAKTHROUGH

Q403_answer.question: Can 'Expressiveness' Be Formally Defined?
Q403_answer.definition: NC-reduction closure size relative to P
levels: Level 1 (Limited): Closure_NC(L) proper subset of P, contains non-NC problems

Q404_answer.question: What Natural Problems Are in P-INTERMEDIATE?

expressiveness_spectrum.name: The Expressiveness Spectrum Theorem
expressiveness_spectrum.statement: Problems in P are characterized by two independent dimensions: DEPTH (circuit depth) and EXPRESSIVENESS (simulation capacity). This gives three classes: NC (low depth), P-INTERMEDIATE (high depth + Level 1), P-complete (high depth + Level 2).

complete_classification.name: The Complete Classification of P
complete_classification.statement: P = NC UNION P-INTERMEDIATE UNION P-complete. This is a complete and exhaustive classification.

natural_witness.name: LP-DAG as Natural P-INTERMEDIATE
natural_witness.statement: Longest Path in DAG (LP-DAG) is in P-INTERMEDIATE: Omega(n) depth due to path dependencies, not P-complete because DAG structure limits encoding.

key_insights: Natural problems exist in P-INTERMEDIATE (not just artificial restrictions)
LP-DAG is a confirmed natural P-INTERMEDIATE witness
Fan-out degree may characterize expressiveness levels

new_questions.question: Is there a hierarchy within Level 1 expressiveness?
Is there a complete problem for P-INTERMEDIATE?
Can expressiveness be computed or approximated?
What is the relationship between P-INTERMEDIATE and other intermediate classes?

building_blocks.Phase 91: P-Complete Depth Theorem (all P-complete need Omega(n))
